may build a road to Berwick's Bay, and the Yankees

After a few further remarks. Governor Moulon
concluded amid loud applause.
It is a source of great regret, that Governor;
Mouton could not be prevailed upon to furnish his
very able and appropriate speech in full. It was ex-]
ceedingly interesting and carried conviction to cv- ]
cry mind, that the country was now ripe for railroad
improvements. To report more of his speech, than
the above meagre outline, penned from brief notes,
would be to do great injustice to this talented gentleman—again we reiterate our regrets that the Governor did not furnish us with a copy, to be printed
with these proceedings.
John E. King, of St. Landry, in response to a
unanimous call, next addressed the meeting in a neat |
and eloquent speech commendatory of Mr. Payne's j
report, and descriptive of the great prospective ad- j
vantages offered by the contemplated project, and
went on to say:
